For color: the alphaNumeric comparator sorts `["-1", "-1.10", "-1.2", "-100", "-2", "0", "1", "1.10", "1.2", "2", "100"]` as `[0, 1, 1.2, 1.10, 2, 100, -1, -1.2, -1.10, -2, -100]`. This is what it does and that is fine (it's only supposed to work on natural numbers).

The numeric comparator should sort them as `[-100, -2, -1.2, -1.10, -1, 0, 1, 1.10, 1.2, 2, 100]`.

Introduced changes of IncrementalIndex to fix NPE which can be thrown when classOfObject() of ObjectColumnSelector for float or long type columns is called, conforming it with that of QueryableIndexStorageAdapter.
@drcrallen looks useful, left some comments in the diff.

Hmm, are we breaking any contract of `Sequence` here? I originally did it with copying instead of in-place since I wasn't sure if it was okay to modify the return values of a sequence in-place.

If this is okay to do, seems like a good change since it should be faster.
FYI, it works by adding "" to dimensionExclusions.

The difference is that in addition to the String type, hadoopyString also supports the Hadoop Text and BytesWritable types. This isn't always necessary but it does let Druid work with more kinds of Hadoop InputFormats.

I raised this PR to adjust the example: #3263. Thanks for the report!

@anonymous-shy We recently updated this doc with tips for getting different Hadoop versions to work: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/docs/content/operations/other-hadoop.md

You might need to download a version of Hadoop dependencies that more closely matches your distribution. Or you could you try setting `mapreduce.job.classpath` to `true` instead of setting `mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first`. With more recent hadoop distributions this seems to work better.

@anonymous-shy it looks like you are using Hadoop 2.6.0 from Cloudera and try to submit a job from Druid compiled against Hadoop 2.3.0, the fix I mentioned is when you use the same or very close version of Hadoop from different distributions (vanilla vs CDH).

I would take a look at the documentation in order to change the Hadoop version Druid pulls:
http://druid.io/docs/0.9.1.1/operations/other-hadoop.html

As well as the `--no-default-hadoop` from 47894c4 recent commit.

Hey @billbargens, the current autoscaling implementation is EC2-based, but you don't need to use galaxy. You can set any userData you want and your AMI can interpret that however it wants.

fwiw "galaxy" refers to: https://github.com/ning/galaxy

addressed comment. thanks.
I don't think `Sequence` has any contract on internal datum mainly because it is for concealing it, imho. Hadoop has long history of reusing objects whenever possible and we might ride the tide.
Seeing #3226, I think it's a natural trend to apply schema on input row. Just a comment.

The kafka documentation states implicitly that it is not recommended to use a kafka-client v0.10 with a kafka 0.9 cluster.

Hi @himanshug, I've managed to reproduce @Digma problem. Basically it seems that druid gives value like `[Ljava.lang.String;@46004d9c` when the data contains at least twice the same list.

```
{"timestamp":1468887263818,"cause_codes":{"array":["A","B"]}}
{"timestamp":1468887299486,"cause_codes":{"array":["A","B"]}}
```

I've attached the sample data and batch job config to reproduce the bug.

[debug_batch_ingest.zip](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/files/374023/debug_batch_ingest.zip)

@sascha-coenen, thanks for the report.

We chose to use kafka-clients 0.9 because it was reported that newer clients don't work with older brokers (see https://groups.google.com/d/msg/confluent-platform/jdv10HahRd8/l-5twegkIAAJ), and we didn't want to require 0.10 brokers just yet.

If downgrading the lz4 version in the extension pom works (s.t. main Druid still uses 1.3.0, but the extension uses 1.2.0 in its own classloader) then that seems like an ideal solution.

Any chance you could check that and confirm if it works or not?

@gianm the extension has the "default" libraries take priority over extension libraries. In this case it wouldn't help because it should pull the class definition from the application classloader rather than the extension one. You'd have to replace replace the application's version to get the change to stick properly.

Awesome! Good to know you got it working.

I'm going to close this ticket, since I think that the approach of (1) pull in your specific matching Hadoop version, and (2) set `mapreduce.job.classpath=true` has worked for the cases we saw so far. We'll be updating our docs in 0.9.2 to recommend that approach.
@acslk we won't need incremental index for groupBy after this right?
@fjy the v2 nested query doesn't need incremental index anymore. I don't believe incremental index was used anywhere else for v2, so yeah.

@acslk Could you¬†please include a test for the bug in #3239? Since I guess it'll still fail for v1, we could have the test expect a failure for v1 and a pass for v2. (along with a comment explaining what's going on)

See `GroupByQueryRunnerTest.testGroupByMaxRowsLimitContextOverrid` for an example of another test that works like that.

rebased
You can keep this from happening, instead favoring killing the task, by adding `druid.indexer.runner.javaOptsArray=["-XX:OnOutOfMemoryError=kill -9 %p"]` to your middle manager runtime properties.
`-XX:+ExitOnOutOfMemoryError` should work too, if you're using java 8u91+.

My posture on this is that `-XX:+ExitOnOutOfMemoryError` is the best way to deal with this. An OOME somewhere deep in the system can throw all sorts of things out of whack if one tries to recover from it, so letting the normal process failure mechanisms deal with that seem best.

I will try using -XX:+ExitOnOutOfMemoryError.  However my larger concern is that my cluster got into a state where no new peons would launch.  No errors in any of the logs.  The overlord indicates that the task was moved into a Running state, but no peon was launched on the middle manager.
@b-slim can you please take care of the comments? lets get this merged.

@benvogan when you're in the state where peons aren't launching, what is the overlord console showing as its view of the state of the system (does it still show the previous tasks that failed with OOM as running or as failed, does it show the middle managers as having any available capacity left)? Also after you restart, do you see logs on the overlord showing the supervisor creating any new tasks, or does it detect the previous tasks as being valid/running and therefore not create a new set of tasks?

Task log is currently a single entry per task containing segment metadata for all segments generated by that task. With the Kafka indexing service being able to create new segments on demand to hold events with arbitrary timestamps + the Kafka indexing service creating a segment per Kafka partition:

long running task \* large range of historical data \* small segment granularities \* lots of Kafka partitions \* big segment metadata (for example lots of dimensions) == massively sized payload

Maybe we should consider splitting the task log table to have separate entries for each segment in a task.
üëç

Hey @pdeva, this is out of scope for what realtime nodes are intended to do ("best effort" reads from an arbitrary streaming source).

But the new Kafka indexing service (http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/extensions-core/kafka-ingestion.html) does handle this in its own way, via transaction checks based on Kafka message offsets. You could take a look at that for stricter behavioral guarantees when reading from Kafka.

Hey @wanyisunflower, there are two kinds of "caching" in Druid. One is your OS's page cache, which caches portions of data segments in memory. Another is Druid's builtin query cache, which caches on a per-query-per-segment basis. The Druid query cache is off by default.

Odds are the effect you noticed was based on the OS's page cache.

If you have some follow up questions, please feel free to post on https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/druid-user (we use github issues more for bugs and feature requests).

Hey @yaochitc, it is generally intended that most users would not use realtime index tasks directly, but would instead go through a higher-level API like [Tranquility](https://github.com/druid-io/tranquility) or the [Kafka indexing service](http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/extensions-core/kafka-ingestion.html).

In particular there are some critical differences between realtime tasks and realtime nodes that mean that firehoses and plumbers designed to work with realtime nodes might not work properly with tasks.

I will close this since even though the API is not the most amazing API in the world, it actually isn't intended to be used directly, so maybe that's okay.

The new [Kafka indexing service](http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/extensions-core/kafka-ingestion.html) is built with the 0.9 client. It also uses the new consumer and we totally do all that nice stuff with controlling offset commits ourselves and not using Kafka's ZooKeeper.
Fixed by #2075
